story: `` Have you ever had the chance to live out your fantasy ? Because I have . I 'm staring into the window of that bitch with only the piss yellow glow of a single street light to keep me warm . Today I will complete my mission . '' *CRASH* The shards of glass from the back window clatter on the ground . I hold my breath and stand in silence , my heart pounding so hard in my chest that I 'm sure she can hear it . After a long and gut wrenching pause I hear nothing but silence . It 's is the loudest silence , deafening even . I slowly reach in and unlock the dead bolt , careful no to scratch myself . I take another beat and check the windows around me . Darkness . Perfect . <newline> Cont ? <newline>

prompt: You are one of the lucky few to be chosen to go to Mars on the Mars One mission . Today is the day of departure .
story:
I stood in the crowded terminal, my heart racing with a mix of excitement and nerves. The day I had been training for, the day I had dreamed of for years, had finally arrived. I was one of the lucky few chosen to embark on the historic Mars One mission, a journey that would take me farther than any human had ever gone before.

As I looked around, I saw the other selected crew members, all of us dressed in our crisp, white spacesuits, our faces set with determination. We had spent years preparing for this moment, training in the harshest conditions, learning every system, every procedure, every contingency. But nothing could truly prepare us for the reality of leaving Earth behind.

The terminal was filled with family members, friends, and well-wishers, all of whom had gathered to bid us farewell. I saw my parents, beaming with pride, my partner, holding back tears. I felt a pang of guilt, knowing that I would be leaving them behind for years, maybe even decades.

The Mars One team, led by the mission commander, Dr. Patel, began to make their way to the spacecraft. We had named her Aurora, after the breathtaking display of light that would greet us as we entered Mars' atmosphere. As we boarded, I felt a sense of awe at the sheer scale of the vessel. It was a marvel of engineering, a self-sustaining ecosystem that would support us for the long journey ahead.

The countdown began, and we strapped ourselves in, our hearts pounding in unison. The engines roared to life, and the Aurora lifted off the launchpad, piercing the sky like a giant arrow. We soared higher and higher, leaving the curvature of the Earth behind, until the blue planet was just a tiny dot on the horizon.

As we broke free of Earth's gravitational pull, I felt a sense of weightlessness, a sense of freedom. We were truly on our own now, hurtling through the vast expanse of space. The stars twinkled like diamonds against the blackness, and I felt infinitesimally small, yet connected to something much greater than myself.

The journey would be long, 225 days to be exact, but we were ready. We had the training, the expertise, and the determination. We would face challenges, of course, but we were a team, a family, united in our quest to explore the unknown.

As I looked out the window, watching the stars whizz by, I felt a sense of wonder, a sense of awe. We were pioneers, blazing a trail that would take humanity to the next great frontier. And I was honored to be a part of it, to be one of the lucky few who would get to experience the thrill of discovery, the thrill of exploration.

The Aurora continued on her journey, carrying us towards the Red Planet, towards a new home, towards a new beginning. I smiled, feeling a sense of excitement, of anticipation. We were on our way, and nothing could stop us now.

prompt: One day you wake up with the ability to control one of the four elements ( Earth , Water , Fire , Air ) . What do you do ?
story: He woke up with cracked lips and the taste of iron on his tongue . Rubbing a pain from his neck , he pushed himself up from the couch , a headache rushing to greet him like an unrelenting wave ; he was parched . <newline> <newline> After a few moments , he trudged to the faucet across the room and placed a cup under it , setting the plunger in its place over the drain as a precaution . He turned the knob and ... nothing . Right . His tank had run out three days past , a detail shrouded by the steady throbbing in his head . <newline> <newline> And there would be no relief . Rains had n't come for over a decade and efforts to resupply any region within a thousand miles of the equator had been abandoned . The heat was intense , the solar flares constant and unabated . Radiation had driven the land to desolation . And the population had moved on , searching for respite closer to the poles as any sane person would . But he could n't , not while she was still here . <newline> <newline> He looked out the window above the sink , glancing at the carved flagstone set upright in the shadow of his old barn across the way . The rust-colored dirt spreading to the horizon was an easy testament to the harshness of it all . His fists clenched at the thought of his past , and pushed away from the counter toward the door . <newline> <newline> He stepped outside , the early sun 's gaze nearly searing his flesh . He looked toward the flagstone again and made his way over , sitting beside the mound in front of it and read the inscription : <newline> <newline> *Dearest Alexandria Ensel* <newline> <newline> *Beloved wife , you are my everything* <newline> <newline> Thirteen years it had been , and each day he had spent time by her grave , with that time growing ever longer since the migrations . He had n't much else to do , after all . <newline> <newline> `` I 've finally ran out , Alex . No more food , no more water . Soon we shall meet again to the sight of green pastures and blue skies . I have longed for it , though I have been afraid . Please , take my hand now and guide me to our new world . '' <newline> <newline> He knew she would n't be fond of his decisions . Her words a few weeks before she passed kept coming back to him . `` *Live , * James . I will be there to pull you through the gates , when the time comes . But do not waste yourself in grief or guilt . Travel . Learn . Do not stay here . '' Well , he was selfish and he had n't left . He could n't leave . <newline> <newline> Tears tried to come , but all was dry . In a moment , blackness took him ... <newline> <newline> He awoke once more to the sun directly overhead , frustration building within him . He rolled to his knees and looked at the grave once more . `` I 'm ready . Take me , give me salvation ! '' he yelled , slamming the side of his clenched fist on packed dirt , and it *sunk in , * coming out lathered in mud . <newline> <newline> He reeled back , shocked . How long it had been since he felt wet . Furrowing his brows , he crawled back and plunged a finger into the small patch that was already shrinking in the heat . It was so cool . He spread the mud on his forearm and readied his fist for another pound , too exhausted to consider the true oddity of what he had done . This time , as it swung , he saw a trail of particles arcing behind his fist , as if materializing out of the air . He stopped the swing and the particles caught up , dousing his arm and creating a light sheen . <newline> <newline> He glanced at the grave , hopelessness taking him . He heard her words repeating again , *Do not stay* . <newline> <newline> `` So this is to be my deliverance , '' he said . And he knew she was right . What use to give up on his world , their first home ? It was not fair for her , and he had wasted far too long in the realization . `` I 'm sorry , Alex . '' <newline> <newline> He licked the water evaporating from his arm , yielding instant relief and offering him a renewed vigor . He reached both hands toward the sky , feeling the water drifting , minute . He grasped , and *pulled , * collecting the water into a small ball before him . It floated there , shifting in the air until he directed it into his mouth , letting it slosh around before swallowing . <newline> <newline> He patted the grave and stood slowly , making his way toward the barn . Years of dust shook off the tarp as he uncovered his old motorcycle . He had kept it in case he ever found the courage to leave , a long abandoned prospect . He filled the tank and set the spare gas into a storage container attached to the back , where he found two cans of beans and some wax-covered cheese that he had forgotten about . It would have to do . He just hoped he could find some additional materials along the way . Fortunately , the engine started and he had naught but gas , beans , cheese , and the clothes on his back to take . And , evidently , water anywhere he could draw it from . He took the bike out front and looked once more at the grave , kneeling to collect some dirt in his hands . `` When we meet again , I shall have many stories for you . <newline> <newline> `` Goodbye Alexandria . ''

prompt: One day you wake up with the ability to control one of the four elements ( Earth , Water , Fire , Air ) . What do you do ?
story:
I woke up to a typical Tuesday morning, or so I thought. As I rolled out of bed, I noticed a strange tingling sensation in my fingers. At first, I brushed it off as a side effect of the new mattress I had just purchased, but as I went about my morning routine, I realized that something was off. The water in my shower was running at an alarming rate, and the plants in my living room were wilting at an alarming pace.

It wasn't until I looked down at my hands and saw that they were glowing with a soft, blue light that I realized what was happening. I had developed the ability to control water.

I was both thrilled and terrified by this newfound power. I had always been fascinated by the ocean and the way it seemed to have a life of its own. Now, I had the ability to tap into that power and manipulate it at will.

As I stood there, frozen in awe, I knew that I had to learn how to control this new ability. I started by experimenting with small things, like turning on the faucet to a gentle trickle or making a small puddle on the floor. It was exhilarating and a little intimidating, but I was determined to master this new skill.

But as the day went on, I realized that my newfound power wasn't just about personal convenience. I could use it to make a real difference in the world. I thought about the drought-stricken areas of the world, where water was scarce and people were struggling to survive. I thought about the pollution in our oceans, and the way that human activity was harming the delicate balance of the ecosystem.

I knew that I had to use my power to help others. I started small, by using my abilities to clean up a nearby park that had been ravaged by pollution. I summoned a gentle rain to wash away the trash and debris, and then used my powers to create a small pond that would provide a source of fresh water for the local wildlife.

As I worked, I felt a sense of purpose that I had never felt before. I was no longer just a ordinary person, but a force of nature with the power to shape the world around me.

But as the sun began to set, I realized that I wasn't the only one who knew about my abilities. A figure appeared on the horizon, watching me with a keen eye. It was a woman with long, flowing hair and a white dress that seemed to shimmer in the fading light.

"Who are you?" I asked, feeling a sense of trepidation.

"I am the guardian of the elements," she replied, her voice low and mysterious. "And you, my dear, are a powerful force to be reckoned with."

I was both thrilled and intimidated by this revelation. I had so many questions, but before I could ask any of them, the woman vanished into thin air, leaving me to ponder the implications of my newfound power.

As I stood there, feeling the weight of my abilities, I knew that I had a long journey ahead of me. But I was ready. I was ready to use my powers to make a difference in the world, and to uncover the secrets of the elements.

prompt: You 're lost at sea after a tremendous storm with fresh water supplies running low . The situation is looking dire . Then you spot him ; a man is swimming towards your boat .
story: It did n't make sense . In the dead of night , when the waters calmed from the great storm , I heard the lapping sound of a swimmer in the water coming towards me . The moon was peaking over the horizon shedding the caps of the waves with a white glow . It was indeed what I thought I was hearing . The object splashed against the whitecaps and made its way towards me . <newline> <newline> The last clouds from the storm flew across the sky , to reveal the stars and Milky Way . It was a beautiful sight as the object reached the edge of my boat . <newline> <newline> Part of me was curious who it may be , while a greater part of me was completely mortified . Its hand reached over like a wet towel being slung across the top of a lounge chair and a few seconds later a head popped up . <newline> <newline> `` Ey , ya , would you help up ? '' said a young man 's voice , the moonlight shining behind his head . <newline> <newline> I scrambled to grab his hand and pulled him into the boat . He was in nothing but a swimsuit and did n't look to be above the age of 25 . <newline> <newline> `` Thanks , '' he said , finding a comfortable corner in the boat to lay in . `` Quite the storm , huh ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Yeah , '' I said . `` I was almost out of food and water before the storm and then it hit . Now I 'm completely out . '' He gave a little chuckle . <newline> <newline> `` I 'm Rudy , '' the man said , giving a brisk wave of his hand . `` I 'm sorry I did n't carry some food and water with me . I thought for sure I would n't be seeing anyone out here tonight . '' <newline> <newline> `` Rudy ? '' I said . `` Ha , that 's my favourite movie . You heard of it ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Of course . Happens to be one of my favourites too , '' he said , sitting up . <newline> <newline> `` What were you doing out here , by the way ? '' I asked . `` I did n't see any ships in the storm . '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh , I just happen to follow storms quite a bit . You could say I like to clean up the messes they leave behind . '' <newline> <newline> I noticed then how cold the night truly was . Wrapped around me was my Thermo blanket and it was keeping me warm , but Rudy had nothing but a swimsuit . <newline> <newline> `` Are n't you cold , '' I asked . `` I think I have another blanket in my emergency kit . '' <newline> <newline> `` Me ? Heck , no . I do n't get cold , '' he said . `` Nope , nope , the cold does n't bother me . '' <newline> <newline> `` So you 're like that marathon runner that runs shirtless in the winter time , '' I said . `` The Iceman , I think his name is ? '' <newline> <newline> Rudy laughed again . `` I guess you could say that . But the 'man ' part might be a bit of a stretch . '' <newline> <newline> His comment caught me off guard . I looked at his with a more careful eye as the moon grew higher in the sky . Somehow I never noticed the set of wings on his back . <newline> <newline> `` You 're an angel ? '' I asked . <newline> <newline> `` Yes , Alex Nuible , '' he said . `` The passage into death is a traumatic one , but every so often we get the chance to see death coming in people . You 've been out to sea for awhile now and with that storm , it was all but definite that the storm would take you . '' <newline> <newline> I realized then the reason I could n't remember seeing any ships during the storm was because I could n't remember the storm . I remember seeing the flashes of lightning on the horizon and the rising waves , but then there was nothing . <newline> <newline> `` Careful ! '' Rudy yelled . `` Think too hard and you will remember the pain , the disparity . I 've cradled you away from that . Let us start the journey to paradise . '' <newline> <newline> `` How do I know this is n't a dream ? '' I asked . `` If I ca n't remember it happening , how do I know it 's real ? '' <newline> <newline> `` You do n't need to know , '' said Rudy . `` The pain will be excruciating , but after you come with me you will see over time that what I 've said is true . Right now reality feels like a dream . It will subside after you 've had time to see that ... you 're not waking up . '' Rudy stood up with a solemn expression and walked towards me with his hand extended . <newline> <newline> I could not accept , though . Even if this was n't a dream , I had to see the truth . I had to know , without a doubt , my end had come . With a burst of speed , I stood up and jumped into the fridged water . The memories came flooding back . <newline> <newline> I saw the great waves of the storm , rising among the lightning . They rocked my boat violently as it rode the crests and sinks . And then it happened . A huge wave formed above and extended its head until I could see the sky no more . The force of the crash plunged me into the deep ocean water where I was lost in the ocean currents . I struggled to find an escape , but my lungs screamed for air while I was still drowned in water . It was a horrific pain , like letting a thousand needles fall into my lungs and trachea . <newline> <newline> In light of the memory , I was no longer in the water , I was in the sky . I saw the moon shining against the surface of the ocean as I soared further and further into the sky . Still hurt from the memory of pain and death , I hung absently in the grip of Rudy as he muttered to himself . <newline> <newline> `` Always so stubborn . I warn them every time . '' <newline> <newline> -- -- -- -- -- -- -- <newline> <newline> Thank you for reading ! More stories at /r/ItsPronouncedGif

prompt: You 're lost at sea after a tremendous storm with fresh water supplies running low . The situation is looking dire . Then you spot him ; a man is swimming towards your boat .
story:
The storm had raged on for what felt like an eternity, its fury unrelenting as it tore through the waves like a beast unleashed from the depths of the ocean. I clung to the side of my small sailboat, my knuckles white with fear as the wind howled and the rain lashed down. The boat creaked and groaned beneath me, its wooden hull straining against the force of the gale.

I had been at sea for days, maybe even weeks, I'd lost all sense of time. The storm had blown in without warning, catching me off guard and sweeping me off course. Now, I was lost, adrift in the vast expanse of the ocean with no sign of land in sight.

My supplies were running low, and I knew I had to conserve what little water I had left. I rationed it carefully, making sure to drink only a small amount each day. But even that was starting to take its toll. My throat was parched, my mouth dry and sticky.

As the storm finally began to subside, I scanned the horizon for any sign of rescue. But there was nothing. No ships, no planes, no signs of life anywhere. I was truly alone.

Just as I was starting to lose hope, I spotted a figure in the distance. At first, I thought it was a wave or a piece of debris, but as it drew closer, I realized it was a man. He was swimming towards my boat, his strokes strong and determined.

My heart leapt with excitement and relief. Could it be? Was this my chance to escape this desolate existence? I waved my arms wildly, shouting for help, but the man didn't seem to hear me. He kept swimming, his eyes fixed on my boat.

As he drew closer, I could see the exhaustion etched on his face. He was a rugged, weathered man, with a thick beard and a scar above his left eyebrow. But despite his rough appearance, there was something about him that seemed... hopeful.

I watched in amazement as he reached the side of my boat and pulled himself up, his muscles straining beneath his skin. He looked at me with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion, his eyes narrowing as he took in my disheveled appearance.

"Who are you?" I asked, my voice shaking with emotion.

The man looked at me for a long moment, then nodded slowly. "I'm Jack," he said, his voice rough and gravelly. "And you are...?"

I smiled, feeling a sense of gratitude wash over me. "I'm... I'm not sure," I admitted, laughing. "I've lost track of time. But I'm glad to have you here, Jack. You're my only hope now."

Jack nodded, a small smile playing on his lips. "We'll get through this together," he said, his voice filled with determination. "We'll find a way to get you back to land, or find a way to fix your boat. We'll make it through this, together."

As I looked at Jack, I felt a sense of hope that I hadn't felt in days. Maybe, just maybe, we would make it out of this alive.

prompt: Fire does n't go out anymore .
story: This is my first one of these , so be gentle . <newline> <newline> Everything Burns . <newline> This is the truth that Humans as a species forgets . <newline> Chicago , London twice before that , and Rome again before that . <newline> Catastrophes like those rare as they are remind us that as humans we can be wiped away by nothing but the whisper of smoke in a burning build or a blaze of roaring red . <newline> Though , we are a resilient bunch and can reduce these burning deaths to embers ... however what if ... we could n't ... <newline> We should 've seen the signs earlier . <newline> An increase in house fires , then wildfires . At first they just became harder to extinguish , firefighters tried to warn people , but no one listened . <newline> Then fires , small at first would appear to spring up on there own . <newline> People began to notice , it was happening too quickly , it should n't be happening people would say . Soon there was mandatory fire fighting training for all civilians , but it was useless . <newline> Then it was realised world round , that fire could no long be tamed , that fire would consume all , that fire burns . <newline> Because now people know . <newline> Everything burns .

prompt: Fire does n't go out anymore .
story:
The world had changed in an instant. It started with small, seemingly insignificant events. A candle that refused to be extinguished, a campfire that continued to burn long after it had been doused, a small spark that refused to be snuffed out. At first, people thought it was just a fluke, a anomaly in the natural order of things.

But as the days turned into weeks, and the weeks turned into months, it became clear that something was amiss. Fires were breaking out everywhere, and they wouldn't go out. Not even with the most advanced fire extinguishers, not even with the most powerful water hoses.

At first, people were excited by the prospect of having an endless supply of heat and light. They would gather around the fires, marveling at their persistence. But as the months turned into years, the excitement wore off, and a sense of unease set in.

The fires were getting bigger, more destructive. They were burning entire cities to the ground, leaving nothing but ashes and rubble in their wake. The air was filled with the acrid smell of smoke, and the once-blue skies were now a perpetual gray.

Governments were powerless to stop the fires, and economies began to collapse. People were forced to live in constant fear of the flames, never knowing when or where the next fire would break out.

A small group of scientists, led by a brilliant but reclusive woman named Dr. Maria Rodriguez, set out to find a solution. They scoured the globe, searching for any clue that might explain the sudden and inexplicable phenomenon.

As they delved deeper into their research, they began to uncover some disturbing truths. It seemed that the fires were not just random events, but were in fact connected to a mysterious energy field that had appeared in the atmosphere.

The energy field, which they dubbed "The Ignis," seemed to be fueled by human activity. The more people burned fossil fuels, the stronger The Ignis grew. And the more it grew, the more destructive the fires became.

Dr. Rodriguez and her team worked tirelessly to find a way to counteract The Ignis, but it seemed like a losing battle. The fires just kept coming, and the world was running out of time.

As the last remnants of civilization burned away, Dr. Rodriguez stood alone, watching as the world went up in flames. She knew that she had failed, and that humanity was doomed.

But even in the face of extinction, there was a glimmer of hope. A small, spark-like flame had appeared in the ruins of a once-great city. It was a tiny, insignificant thing, but it was a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there was always a chance for rebirth.

The flame flickered and danced, a tiny beacon of light in a world gone mad. And as Dr. Rodriguez watched, she knew that as long as that flame burned, there would always be a chance for humanity to rise again.

prompt: A man hires a hit man on himself , with a note saying `` This will not be easy . ''
story: `` I 've gotten myself into quite a pickle , '' my client told me , `` So I 'm trying to get rid of some loose ends . '' <newline> <newline> I simply assumed he did some crime , got away , and did n't want his partners to rat him out . I 've gotten these kinds of jobs before . Standard . Simple . Kill some poor asshole that got himself into a sticky situation . <newline> <newline> Holy shit , was I wrong . <newline> <newline> I went to the address disclosed for me . I found myself standing in front of small house , the wooden shutters decaying from time . The stairs on the porch looked like they were about to crumble if I coughed on them . For all I cared , the house could have been a pile of rocks , as long as I still got paid . <newline> <newline> The instructions I were given dictated me to knock on the door and follow the person that answered it . So I did . A pale man with a well-tailored suit silently greeted me into the abode . He simply began walking and I followed after closing the door behind me . I was alert , on edge , ready to take on my job . <newline> My instructions went on to detail how the man would lead me into a basement , where I was to receive further orders . I went downstairs . I thought I was prepared for whatever sight would greet me . What I saw then , I still ca n't explain today . It was just a job . <newline> <newline> I found my client . Twice , in fact . At once . I instantly recognized his face from the news ; he was a suspect in a bank robbery , and right now , he seemed pretty fucking guilty . He stood in the dingy basement , a huge duffle bag of what I assumed was cash behind him , and next to a chair with a restrained man . The man was an exact copy of him . Spot on , the beard , the hair cut , the small mole on his left cheek . <newline> <newline> `` Hi , '' the 'him ' standing up said , `` I 'm sure you have a lot of questions . '' <newline> <newline> I did , but that was unprofessional . I shook my head in response . I just wanted to get this weird shit over with . `` Good , '' he said , `` I need you to kill me . THIS me ! '' He quickly corrected . <newline> <newline> He continued , `` Yeah , I 'm sure you recognize me . I just pulled off a heist . I needed to be in two places at once , so I made a clone . '' <newline> <newline> I only thought how . <newline> <newline> `` I 'm pretty scientifically talented , '' he said in reply to my confused expression , `` I want you to kill him . It . Me , whatever the fuck . I 'm tying up loose ends . '' <newline> <newline> `` Why would you hire a hit man to do it ? '' I asked . <newline> <newline> `` Look man I 'm a bank robber , but not a murderer . Plus he looks just like me ! Think you 'd be able to do the same ? Just do the job and I 'll pay you , dude . '' <newline> <newline> I looked at the clone sitting in the chair , tied up . He looked at me with tired , red eyes . His sorrowful expression . `` Do n't do it man , '' he said , `` He 's lying . I remember everything in my life . I 'm an actual person . *He's* the clone ! Have some god damn morals ! '' <newline> <newline> `` I 'm just doing a job , '' I replied . <newline> <newline> `` I 'll pay you too ! '' He shouted back before being silenced by a punch to the face by the standing man . <newline> <newline> The two started yelling back and forth . At me . At each other . I zoned out , closed my eyes . I blocked them out and drew my gun . <newline> <newline> -- -- -- <newline> <newline> The news was interesting the next day . `` BANK HEIST SUSPECTS FOUND ! TWIN BROTHER ALSO INVOLVED ! THREE BODIES AT SITE ! MONEY NOWHERE TO BE FOUND ! '' The headlines read . <newline> <newline> I parked my new car at my new house . I still had some junk money left over . It would take a while for the rest to be laundered , but it would last me the rest of my life if I was smart about it . All my loose ends were tied and I covered my tracks . Some other poor bastard would be getting arested for what I did . After all , the event was just a job , and I still got paid in the end .

prompt: A man hires a hit man on himself , with a note saying `` This will not be easy . ''
story:
The rain poured down on the city like a dirty blanket, shrouding the streets in a misty gloom. Jack Harris stood outside the dingy bar, a crumpled cigarette dangling from his lip. He was a man with a plan, and a plan that required a certain... delicacy.

Inside, the bartender polished a mug with a dirty rag, eyeing Jack with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. Jack slid onto a stool, his eyes scanning the room before coming to rest on a figure in the corner. A man with a reputation for getting the job done, no matter the cost.

"Vinnie," Jack said, his voice low and even. "I need a favor."

Vinnie looked up, his eyes narrowing as he took in Jack's disheveled appearance. "What kind of favor?" he asked, his tone dripping with skepticism.

"I need you to... take care of me," Jack said, his words dripping with irony. "I've got a problem, Vinnie. A problem that requires... professional attention."

Vinnie's expression didn't change, but Jack could see the gears turning in his head. "You're talking about a hit, aren't you?" he asked, his voice dripping with disdain.

Jack nodded, a small smile playing on his lips. "I'm talking about a hit, Vinnie. And I want you to be the one to do it."

Vinnie's eyes widened in surprise, but Jack could see the calculation in his eyes. He knew that Vinnie was a man who didn't do favors for free, and he certainly didn't do them for people who were asking to be killed.

"What's in it for me?" Vinnie asked, his voice dripping with expectation.

Jack pulled out a small envelope from his pocket and slid it across the bar. Vinnie's eyes widened as he opened it, revealing a stack of crisp, new bills.

"Enough to set you up for life," Jack said, his voice dripping with sincerity. "But I need you to do it quickly, Vinnie. I've got... arrangements to make."

Vinnie's expression didn't change, but Jack could see the wheels turning in his head. He knew that Vinnie was a man who valued his freedom, and he certainly didn't want to be tied down to a job that required him to take a life.

"Okay, Jack," Vinnie said finally, his voice dripping with reluctance. "I'll do it. But you need to understand, this is going to be hard. Really hard."

Jack nodded, a small smile playing on his lips. "I know, Vinnie. That's why I hired you."

The note on the table read: "This will not be easy." Jack smiled to himself as he stood up to leave. He knew that Vinnie would do the job, no matter what it took. And when he was done, Jack would be nothing more than a memory.

The rain continued to pour down as Jack walked out of the bar, disappearing into the night. Vinnie watched him go, a mixture of emotions swirling in his head. He knew that he had just made a deal with the devil, and he wasn't sure if he would ever be able to escape.

The hit was set for midnight. The city would be dark and deserted, the perfect place for a man to disappear into the night. And when it was all over, Vinnie would be left to pick up the pieces, wondering if he had just made a terrible mistake.

prompt: Every time you go to defecate , you poop out black and brown reptilian creatures shaped like turds with human eyes , and when you flush they cry like human babies .
story: My diet is strictly liquid . You guys have heard of that Soylent shit , right ? Same thing , more or less . Everything I need . All the nutrients and electrolytes and whatever-the-hell that keep my system in running order . Each daily dose spread across three separate bottles . It ’ s been that way ever since the shit-monsters materialized . <newline> <newline> Taking liquid shits isn ’ t so bad , I guess . I had to move from single-ply economy toilet paper to extra soft to extra soft plus moisturizing lotion to baby wipes . But there ’ s a bear on the box and it looks kinda cute sitting on the cistern of my toilet . Plus I don ’ t have to worry about which direction to place the roll , so I guess I ’ ve got that going for me . <newline> <newline> But Jesus . I hate . Hate hate hate hate . Hate more than I have hated anything else . Hate more than I hate terrorism and ebola and Donald Trump ’ s political campaign . Fucking hate the lack of variety in my meals . Sure , I ’ ve lost fifteen pounds . Sure , it ’ s cheaper in the long run . And sure , I don ’ t have to deal with the hassle of finding a new home for my crying , screaming shit-monsters . But I really miss solid food . Real food . Food I can chew up . Steak . Crusty warm bread with the soft chewy inside that I have gnash with my molars into a glutenous blob before I can swallow it down . It ’ s awful . <newline> <newline> So , I cheated . <newline> <newline> Most people have a slip-up now and then . And yeah , if I ’ m honest with you right now , I don ’ t regret it one bit . So sue me . I wanted food of substance . It ’ s a natural desire . We ’ re fighting millions of years of evolution here , folks . It ’ s not like I committed some kind of cardinal sin . My teeth and the little biome in my stomach didn ’ t evolve to process this synthetic liquid garbage . <newline> <newline> Finding solid food is hard if you don ’ t know where to look for it . There are still fringe groups of traditionalists who have all run outside to live off the grid and off the land , but they ’ re a select few and kind of culty . That weird stuff always freaks me out . And you can always find someone in some alley somewhere who ’ s got an old bag of Skittles , but that ’ ll cost you an arm and a leg and you might end up getting shot for it . But I ’ m just a normal guy . I don ’ t wan na do some backalley deal or sell my soul to some random Jim Jones wannabe asshole in Backwater , Utah ( pop . 43 ) . <newline> <newline> And so I found myself on Darknet buying a six year-old can of SpaghettiOs for the equivalent of 150 bucks in cyptocurrency . Not a great deal , but not awful either . Plus they promise me prompt and discreet shipping . Worth every penny . <newline> <newline> When the food arrived on my doorstep in a plain brown box with no identifying marks for my privacy , I was fuckin ’ floored . I scooped it up and took it into my kitchen . I drew closed the shades and made sure my blinds were shut . I opened up the can and dug in with my fingers , eating handful after handful of lukewarm SpaghettiOs . <newline> <newline> It was glorious . The gritty blandness of chugging down bottle after bottle of Generic Human Dietary Fluid 2A-3E was a shadow of a nightmare in my mind . I crushed the noodles in my teeth and slurped up their tomato-y substrate . This is what we were meant to eat . This is real food . <newline> <newline> But now I ’ m sitting in my car with my hands on the steering wheel—parked and waiting . There are picketers with angry signs moving up and down the block . Scary picketers . Violent , religious nutjobs . I want them to leave . The sign above the door of the building I ’ m parked outside of reads Planned Evacuation . My stomach churns and rumbles . It ’ s not used to solid food . <newline> <newline> I wait for the line of picketers to move as far away from the door as possible before I undo my seatbelt and make my way out of the car . I bet if I told you five years ago that prune juice was going to be considered an abortifacient , you would have laughed your fucking head off . <newline>

prompt: Every time you go to defecate , you poop out black and brown reptilian creatures shaped like turds with human eyes , and when you flush they cry like human babies .
story:
I stared at the toilet, my heart racing with a mix of fascination and horror. It was a ritual I had grown accustomed to over the years, but one that still left me questioning my sanity. Every time I needed to defecate, I would feel a strange, unsettling sensation in my bowels. It was as if my body was preparing me for something more than just a simple bowel movement.

And then, it would happen.

A black and brown reptilian creature, shaped like a turd, would emerge from my rectum. But it wasn't just any creature - it had human eyes, staring back at me with a mixture of confusion and terror. I would try to ignore it, to pretend it wasn't there, but it was impossible. The creature would look up at me, and I could swear I saw a glimmer of recognition in its eyes.

As I stood there, frozen in shock, the creature would begin to cry. Not just any cry, but a wail that sounded uncannily like a human baby's. It was a sound that sent shivers down my spine, and I couldn't help but feel a pang of guilt.

I would try to flush the creature down the toilet, but it would resist, flailing its tiny arms and legs in a desperate bid to escape. And then, the crying would grow louder, more insistent. It was as if the creature was trying to tell me something, to convey a message that I couldn't quite understand.

I had tried to research this phenomenon, to find some explanation for it. But every doctor, every scientist, every expert I spoke to seemed just as baffled as I was. It was as if my body was defying all logic, all reason.

I began to dread going to the bathroom, to fear the creatures that would emerge from my bowels. But I knew I couldn't avoid it forever. So, I took a deep breath, and stepped into the bathroom.

As I sat down, I felt the familiar sensation building inside me. And then, it happened. A black and brown reptilian creature, shaped like a turd, emerged from my rectum. It looked up at me, its human eyes staring back, and I felt a jolt of recognition.

The creature began to cry, its wails echoing off the walls of the bathroom. I felt a surge of guilt, of shame. What was I doing to these creatures? Why were they being forced to endure this?

I tried to flush the creature down the toilet, but it resisted, flailing its tiny arms and legs in a desperate bid to escape. And then, the crying grew louder, more insistent. It was as if the creature was trying to tell me something, to convey a message that I couldn't quite understand.

As I stood there, frozen in shock, I realized that I had a choice to make. I could continue to ignore the creatures, to pretend they weren't there. Or I could try to understand them, to find a way to communicate with them.

It was a daunting task, but I knew I had to try. For the creatures, for myself, I had to try.

prompt: Write an alt history where another sentient race evolved alongside humans , and now we live in harmony/conflict with them
story: It was a Monday morning when I woke up , groggy from a short sleep . The sky was still dark and all was quiet , so it came to my surprise that my dad was awake in a sort of silent trance , his eyes bloodshot and full of rage . <newline> <newline> `` I ca n't believe this , '' he said , `` this whole country has gone to shit ! '' <newline> <newline> `` Morning , dad . '' I replied . The TV had its sound muted but what he was angry at was quite obvious . It was on the news channel and the headline *ZUAFFYUL X-2739 ELECTED AS PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES* I was wholly indifferent to politics , I had no opinion on the matter . <newline> <newline> `` Do you understand what this means , son ? '' His voice sounded genuinely scared , which I felt was an overreaction . `` We 've got to leave the country . This is the first step in a slippery slope . Eventually he 's going to announce the genocide of humans to massive applause . And we voted for him ! Ha ! '' <newline> <newline> I decided not to argue as I needed to get ready for school . My phone beeps as I brush my teeth - text message from Zeolharxyon `` Z '' Y-6357 . I picked up my phone and read it . <newline> <newline> `` Parents are crying . Never thought that this day would come . So happy right now , see you at school . '' <newline> <newline> Z was my best friend at school . The fact that today , for the first time ever , one of his kind was elected president made me extremely happy . I made sure to hide this happiness from my father the rest of the morning before heading to school .

prompt: Write an alt history where another sentient race evolved alongside humans , and now we live in harmony/conflict with them
story:
**The Coexistence of Humans and Aethers**

In the early 21st century, a team of scientists made a groundbreaking discovery that would change the course of human history forever. Deep in the Amazon rainforest, they stumbled upon an ancient civilization of sentient beings known as the Aethers. These ethereal creatures, with their slender bodies and iridescent skin, had evolved alongside humans for thousands of years, living in a delicate balance of power and coexistence.

The Aethers possessed a unique connection to the natural world, allowing them to manipulate the elements with a mere thought. They could summon the winds, conjure fire from thin air, and even communicate with the creatures of the forest. Humans, with their primitive understanding of the world, were both fascinated and intimidated by the Aethers' abilities.

As news of the Aethers spread, the world was thrown into chaos. Some nations saw the Aethers as a threat, a rival species that could potentially disrupt the balance of power. Others viewed them as a blessing, a chance to learn from and collaborate with a being of such immense power.

The United Nations, in an effort to establish a framework for coexistence, created the Aether-Human Accord. The treaty established clear guidelines for Aether-human interactions, including the protection of Aether territories and the prohibition of Aether exploitation. However, the Accord was not without its flaws. Some nations, like the United States, saw the Aethers as a means to gain an economic advantage, while others, like China, viewed them as a potential military threat.

As the years passed, humans and Aethers learned to live together, albeit uneasily. Aethers became integral to various industries, from agriculture to energy production. They worked alongside humans, using their unique abilities to create innovative solutions to pressing global problems.

However, tensions simmered beneath the surface. Some Aethers resented the way humans had exploited their knowledge and resources, while humans grew increasingly dependent on Aether labor. The divide between the two species deepened, and conflicts began to erupt.

One such conflict occurred in the city of New Eden, where a group of Aethers, dissatisfied with their working conditions, staged a protest. The humans, fearing for their safety, responded with force, leading to a violent confrontation. The incident sparked a global outcry, with many calling for greater Aether rights and protections.

In the aftermath, the United Nations was forced to re-examine the Accord. A new, more comprehensive agreement was drafted, one that recognized the Aethers' autonomy and rights. The treaty established Aether-human councils, where representatives from both species could negotiate and resolve disputes.

Today, humans and Aethers coexist in a fragile harmony. While conflicts still arise, they are fewer and farther between. The Aethers continue to evolve, their connection to the natural world deepening with each passing year. Humans, in turn, have come to appreciate the Aethers' unique perspective, learning to respect and value their contributions.

As we look to the future, it is clear that the relationship between humans and Aethers will continue to shape the course of history. Will we find a way to truly live in harmony, or will the tensions between us tear us apart? Only time will tell.

In the midst of this complex, ever-changing world, one thing is certain: the coexistence of humans and Aethers is a double-edged sword, full of promise and peril. As we navigate the intricate web of our relationships, we must remember that the future is not set in stone, but rather, it is a tapestry of choices, waiting to be woven.

story: He stood there , looking as his own grave . <newline> <newline> Fog hung low in the air , the visceral substance forming an eerie wall around the lonely cemetery . <newline> <newline> The dirt caked on his boots seemed to weigh him down , anchoring the dejected man to his spot . Even if he wanted to run , he would be tethered here by obligation . <newline> <newline> `` Do it , Francis . '' A voice sounded somewhere behind the troubled man , but he did n't turn around to acknowledge it . Yet for some reason , it continued to speak . `` You know why you 're here . We all know why . '' <newline> <newline> The man could hear footsteps behind him , yet he still did n't turn . <newline> <newline> `` You *killed* her , Francis . It 's all your fault . '' <newline> <newline> `` No . '' The man uttered the word feebly at first , unsure of its validity . He said it again , this time more firmly . `` NO . '' <newline> <newline> Turning around , Francis confronted his accusers . The gaunt face of a woman stared hard at him ; behind her stood myriad cloaked individuals , their faces hidden from view . <newline> <newline> `` Jessica is dead and it 's all your fault , Francis . '' <newline> <newline> `` It was n't my fault . You 're wrong . '' <newline> <newline> `` It was . You simply ca n't admit it . You can never take responsibility . '' <newline> <newline> `` Shut UP ! You have no idea what you 're talking about- '' <newline> <newline> `` I know *exactly* what I 'm talking about ! '' The woman began to move in closer to Francis , her tone becoming more and more menacing . `` The whole town knows what you 've done ! *She* knows what you 've done ! '' <newline> <newline> The woman pointed past Francis at the grave he had been pensively considering prior . The man turned , wide-eyed in horror . <newline> <newline> A small child , a girl , was climbing out of the grave , eyes sunken , skin pale . Her matted hair obscured her features , but Francis knew exactly who she was . He wanted with all his being to scream , to run , to move from the spot where he currently stood . But he could n't . He was anchored in place . <newline> <newline> `` NO . '' The only word that the man could say began to sound like a confirmation . `` No , no , no , no NO ! '' <newline> <newline> The child grabbed Francis by his shirt , ripping the man forward , shattering his unseen tether . She pulled him to the edge of the grave , just enough for him to lose his balance . The man toppled over the edge , crashing down to the earthen floor below . <newline> <newline> `` I 'm sorry , '' Francis sobbed . He laid in the dirt , curled up in a fetal position . `` I 'm sorry , I 'm sorry , I 'm *so* , *so sorry* . '' <newline> <newline> The man stayed there for a while . He had no grasp on the passing of time . When he finally raised his head , there was no girl , there was no crowd gathered at the edge of the grave , there was no woman with her sharp words . <newline> <newline> Just him , his guilt , and his grave .

prompt: He stood there , looking at his own grave .
story:
The sun beat down on the weathered headstone, its inscription worn by time and the elements. John's eyes, sunken and weary, gazed upon the simple yet poignant epitaph: "John, Beloved Husband, Father, and Friend. Died 10th February 2005, Aged 42." The words seemed to mock him, a cruel reminder of the life he had lived, the dreams he had pursued, and the loved ones he had left behind.

As he stood there, the silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional chirping of birds or the rustling of leaves in the nearby trees. John's mind wandered back to the day he had chosen this spot, this moment, to end his life. It was a decision he had made in the depths of despair, when the weight of his struggles had become too much to bear.

He thought of his wife, Sarah, and their two children, Emily and James. They had been his world, his reason for living. He remembered the laughter, the tears, the countless moments of joy and heartache they had shared together. And now, he was gone, leaving them with a gaping hole in their lives that could never be filled.

John's eyes drifted to the nearby cemetery, where countless others lay buried, their stories and memories lost to the sands of time. He wondered if they, too, had stood at their own graves, contemplating the what-ifs and the maybes. Did they, like him, regret their choices, their paths not taken?

As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the landscape, John felt a sense of peace wash over him. It was a fleeting feeling, one that he knew would soon be replaced by the familiar pangs of regret and longing. But for now, he allowed himself to indulge in the fantasy that he was still alive, that he was still walking alongside Sarah and the children, sharing in their joys and sorrows.

He closed his eyes, and for a moment, he was back in the present, surrounded by the people he loved. He felt the warmth of Sarah's hand in his, the softness of Emily's hair, and the mischievous grin of James. The pain and the sorrow receded, replaced by a sense of contentment and belonging.

But the moment passed, and John's eyes snapped open. He was alone, standing in front of his own grave, surrounded by the cold, hard earth and the silence of the dead. The weight of his decision crashed down upon him once more, and he felt the familiar sense of despair creeping back in.

With a heavy heart, John turned and walked away, leaving behind the only home he had ever known. As he disappeared into the distance, the sun dipped below the horizon, casting the cemetery in a dark, foreboding shadow. The grave, once a symbol of his mortality, now stood as a reminder of the choices he had made, and the life he had left behind.

prompt: You have the power that whenever you tell a lie and someone believes you it becomes true . You 're talking to the president and he 's believing everything you 're saying .
story: `` So that 's why , Mr. President , '' I said , `` They call it 'super-sized ' . It 's all because Ray Kroc had a philosophical fling with Nietzche when he was younger ! I mean , can you believe it ? '' <newline> <newline> The president looked at me with wide eyes , his jaw hanging open . <newline> <newline> `` My goodness , '' he said , `` I did not know that , and I would n't have believed it if I had n't heard it from you . '' He picked up his scotch and kicked back what was remaining and slammed the heavy glass down . He poured himself another and held up the bottle and shook it at me . <newline> <newline> I nodded and he poured me one as well , a heavy pour . <newline> <newline> `` And you know , '' he said , `` That 's probably how they came up with Superman too . '' He dropped two chunks of ice in his drink , one chunk in mine . `` Nietzche . Chiristopher Reeve as Nietzche and all that , I betcha . '' <newline> <newline> `` Actually , '' I said , `` the creator of Superman named hero that after the drycleaner he used to take his shirts to get pressed . The place was called Super Men 's Super Shirts and Laundry . Made 'em famous . '' <newline> <newline> Well shit , he said , `` Is n't the world just great ? '' <newline> <newline> He poked his left hand at the pocket of his trousers a few times before it found its way in and withdrew a pack of smokes . He asked me if I wanted one and I said sure and we picked up our drinks and walked over to the open French doors . He flipped me a cigarette and I lit them both . <newline> <newline> `` Shit , '' he said , `` Is n't it a pretty night ? '' He looked out at the rose garden and exhaled a plume of smoke . I nodded . '' I nodded again and took a long swig of the scotch . <newline> <newline> `` You know , '' I said , I just read a study out of MIT that found that they are n't bad for you at all ... that they 're kind of healthy for you . '' <newline> <newline> `` No shit ? '' he said . <newline> <newline> `` No shit , '' I replied . `` They found that they actually improve your lung capacity , and they put hair on your chest . He open his eyes and blew out the smoke . <newline> <newline> `` Well if this is n't nice , what is ? '' he said .

prompt: You have the power that whenever you tell a lie and someone believes you it becomes true . You 're talking to the president and he 's believing everything you 're saying .
story:
I stood nervously in the Oval Office, fidgeting with my hands as I gazed up at the President of the United States. I had always been fascinated by the inner workings of the White House, and now, here I was, face to face with the most powerful man in the country.

As we shook hands, I couldn't help but think about the power that lay within me. The power to shape reality with a single word. The power to make the impossible possible. And the power to deceive, to manipulate, to bend the truth to my will.

The President, a tall, imposing figure with a firm handshake, smiled warmly at me. "Welcome, welcome," he said. "I'm glad you could make it. I've heard great things about your... unique perspective."

I smiled back, feeling a sense of confidence wash over me. "Thank you, Mr. President," I said. "I'm honored to be here."

As we sat down, I began to spin a tale. "You know, Mr. President," I said, "I've always been fascinated by the art of diplomacy. In fact, I've spent years studying the great diplomats of history, from Napoleon to Kennedy."

The President's eyes lit up. "Really?" he said. "I've always been a fan of Kennedy myself. His leadership during the Cuban Missile Crisis was truly inspiring."

I nodded, feeling a sense of pride. "Yes, exactly," I said. "And I've always believed that the key to successful diplomacy is to be able to think on your feet, to be able to adapt to any situation."

The President leaned forward, his eyes locked intently on mine. "I couldn't agree more," he said. "In fact, I've been thinking of implementing a new policy of 'think on your feet' diplomacy. What do you think?"

I grinned, feeling a sense of excitement. "I think it's a great idea, Mr. President," I said. "In fact, I've been working on a proposal for just that. I'd be happy to share it with you."

As we continued to talk, I spun more and more elaborate lies. The President listened with rapt attention, his eyes shining with excitement. And with each passing minute, I felt my power growing stronger.

I told him that I had a team of experts working on a top-secret project to develop a new source of clean energy. I told him that I had been in secret negotiations with world leaders to establish a new global economy. And I told him that I had a plan to eradicate poverty and hunger from the face of the earth.

And with each passing lie, the President believed me. And with each passing lie, the world around us began to change. The air seemed to grow cleaner, the oceans seemed to fill with new life, and the streets seemed to fill with the sound of laughter and music.

As the meeting drew to a close, I felt a sense of exhilaration. I had never felt so powerful in my life. And as I stood up to leave, the President turned to me with a smile.

"Thank you, my friend," he said. "You've given me a lot to think about. I look forward to seeing the results of your proposal."

I smiled back, feeling a sense of pride. "Thank you, Mr. President," I said. "It's been an honor."

As I left the Oval Office, I couldn't help but wonder what other lies I could tell, what other truths I could create. The power was intoxicating, and I knew that I would never be able to stop.

prompt: I need help finding my passion .
story: I want to share with you something that I discovered about myself that rekindled my passion for writing . You need to fall in love with yourself and the words coming out of you . It 's very easy to get bored with writing , your plot , whatever . Writing , like cooking , needs herbs , spices and variety . If you cook a frozen burger adding nothing extra , that burger is going to be plain . <newline> <newline> I use the burger analogy when explaining writing to friends . I ask them : Which sounds better ... A ) Jack put a frozen burger on the grill . After a while , it was done and he ate it . Or B ) Jack had before him a bowl . Ground sirloin beef was mixed with a beaten egg , Italian bread crumbs , worcestershire sauce , minced garlic and a few pinches of cayenne pepper . The charcoal grill had already been burning red hot when he added the soaked hickory woodchips on the fire . The patties were seared as the flames licked the side of the meat . He took a swig of the whiskey , it warmed his belly and reminded him of his father . He had always said a man should never grill sober . <newline> <newline> The freshly done burgers had perfect grill lines across both sides . He had only flipped them a single time , it 's the rule . They had been topped with a thick slice of cheddar cheese , three slice of bacon and a single leaf of lettuce . You had to get veggies in your system , somehow . He had baked the sourdough buns himself , they had been timed to come out of the oven just moments before the food was off the grill . It would be a satisfying meal , the juices of the hot meal running down the sides of his hands . The satisfying crunch of the bacon mingling with the slightly burnt texture of the scores from the steel grating of the grill . <newline> <newline> -- -- -- - <newline> <newline> I know , it 's a long example . When I explain it to friends ... when I explained it to myself , even ... I learned that I love making that fully realized burger . I like putting that piece of freshly done food in their mouth . You 've got to rekindle that interest in cooking up a story . You need to figure out what flavors you actually like . If you start but never finish anything , you need to diagnose what that is . Are you not interested in the final product ? Then you 're cooking the wrong story . Are you vested in the final product , but the work to get to that end is n't satisfying ? You need to start mixing in different ingredients , adding flourishes , seeing things that other people do n't see or do n't give much attention to . <newline> <newline> Bottom line : You need to make things interesting for you . Challenge yourself to make even the most mundane thing , like cooking a burger , sound interesting . Otherwise it will taste as bland as it feels . I hope this helps .

prompt: I need help finding my passion .
story:
As I sat in the small café, sipping on a lukewarm coffee, I couldn't help but feel a sense of restlessness. Another day, another dollar, another series of tasks to complete, but what was the point of it all? I felt like a cog in a machine, just going through the motions without any sense of purpose.

I had always been told that I needed to find my passion, that it was the key to happiness and fulfillment. But what was my passion? I had tried everything – art, music, sports, even cooking – but nothing seemed to stick. I felt like I was searching for a needle in a haystack, with no idea where to start.

As I sat there, staring blankly at the wall, a woman with a kind face and a warm smile walked in. She took a seat next to me and introduced herself as Sophia, a life coach who specialized in helping people find their purpose.

I hesitated at first, but something about Sophia's gentle demeanor put me at ease. I told her about my struggles, about feeling lost and unfulfilled. She listened attentively, nodding her head and making supportive noises.

When I finished, Sophia smiled and said, "I think I can help you." She pulled out a small notebook and began to ask me a series of questions. What did I enjoy doing in my free time? What made me feel most alive? What were my values and passions?

As we talked, I began to realize that I had been focusing on the wrong things. I had been trying to find my passion in the wrong places – in the wrong activities, with the wrong people. But Sophia's questions helped me to see that my passion was within me all along.

She asked me to think about my childhood, about what I used to love doing when I was a kid. I remembered spending hours playing in the woods, exploring the creek, and collecting leaves. I remembered feeling a sense of wonder and awe, of being completely absorbed in the moment.

Sophia smiled when I mentioned this. "That's it," she said. "That's your passion. You've been trying to find it in the wrong places, but it's been right in front of you all along."

I felt a surge of excitement and hope. Could it be true? Could I really find my passion in the simple things, in the things that brought me joy and fulfillment?

Sophia gave me a task to do – to spend the next week doing something I loved, something that made me feel alive. I was to explore the woods, to collect leaves, to watch the sunset. And I was to do it without any expectations, without any pressure.

As I left the café, I felt a sense of freedom and possibility. I knew that I still had a long way to go, but I was excited to start the journey. I was excited to see where my passion would take me, and what it would bring me.

And as I walked out into the bright sunlight, I felt a sense of hope and optimism that I hadn't felt in a long time. Maybe, just maybe, I was on the right path. Maybe I was finally going to find my passion, and in doing so, find my true self.

prompt: Aliens have landed and are instilling everyone with a super power based on their natural abilities . You however are extremely disappointed in yours .
story:
I stood at the edge of the city square, surrounded by the hum of excitement and the chatter of my fellow humans. The aliens, tall and slender with skin like polished obsidian, stood at the center, their large, black eyes scanning the crowd. They had come to bestow upon us a gift – a superpower, tailored to our unique abilities.

As the lead alien, a being with an androgynous face and piercing green eyes, raised its hands, a warm, golden light enveloped the square. The air vibrated with anticipation, and I felt a strange tingling sensation in my fingertips.

The light dissipated, and the aliens began to chant in unison. The words were incomprehensible, but their tone was soothing, and I felt my body begin to respond. A surge of energy coursed through my veins, and I raised my hands to see what had been bestowed upon me.

A faint glow emanated from my fingertips, but it was nothing remarkable. I was a writer, not a warrior. I had always been content with my words, but now, I felt like a mere mortal, lacking in the grandeur of the superpowers I had seen bestowed upon others.

A young athlete, a sprinter, had been given the power of super speed. A musician had been gifted with the ability to create sonic blasts. Even a child had been transformed into a being of pure energy, capable of manipulating the very fabric of reality.

But me? I was given... the power of... being able to organize my desk drawers more efficiently.

I stared at my hands in dismay. The glow was there, but it was a dull, feeble light, barely illuminating the dust bunnies that had accumulated under my desk. I felt like a joke, a mere mortal, reduced to the mundane.

The aliens, sensing my disappointment, approached me. Their leader spoke in a gentle voice, "Your power, human, is not to be underestimated. The ability to organize your surroundings is a gift, one that will bring you great joy and satisfaction."

But I was not convinced. I had always dreamed of being a hero, of saving the world from danger. Now, I was stuck with a power that would only serve me well in a world where the most pressing threat was a cluttered desk.

As the crowd dispersed, I wandered away from the square, feeling like a failure. I had always been content with my words, but now, I felt like a mere mortal, lacking in the grandeur of the superpowers I had seen bestowed upon others.

I sat down at my desk, surrounded by the chaos of papers and pens, and let out a deep sigh. My power, it seemed, was not a gift, but a curse. I was a writer, and my superpower was being able to organize my desk drawers more efficiently. The irony was not lost on me.

As I began to sort through my papers, I couldn't help but wonder what the aliens had been thinking. Had they truly thought that this was the best they could do? I shook my head, feeling a sense of resignation wash over me. I was a writer, and my superpower was being able to organize my desk drawers more efficiently. It was a power that would change the world, or at least, my desk.

prompt: The Cocaine God
story: I was ushered into a dark room , where I see a man sitting in the dark wearing a black suit and his gold chain shining in what little light is in the room . I 'm thrown onto the ground . I know why I 'm here . The last words I want to hear come out of his mouth `` Where my money ? '' I start crying trying to explain where my mom has went . BAM ! I get kicked in the face . `` WHERES MY FUCKING MONEY ! ? '' <newline> <newline> Two weeks later , I 'm sitting in my apartment shaking from withdraw . I have been doing cocaine for too damn long . All my money is being sucked away by this terrible habit formed from parting to much . `` What have I done ? '' The sweat drips down my forehead as I hear my phone buzz . I pick it up . The text reads `` You want some more of the good stuff ? '' A giant smile grows on my face . I respond letting my dealer know that I 'm in dire need of a hookup but , spent all of my money earlier . Kevin , my dealer , texts back with `` I can give you some now , but , you 'll have to pay more when you do get money . '' I agree . I get the cocaine and never speak to him again . <newline> <newline> Two weeks later . My door gets a knock on it . I have no clue who could be at the door at 9 p.m . I try to look through my peep hole , but , its shattered . I open the door cautiously . I 'm punched and I fall to the ground . I catch a glimpse of two people in leather jackets before I pass out . I wake up in the back of a car . I have no clue what is going on . We stop . The trunk opens and a man in staring at me . He pulls me out and drags me into a building I had never seen . The smell of his cologne could cover a dumpster . I was ushered in and thrown onto the floor . <newline> <newline> A man sitting in the dark room was what I saw . <newline> I had only heard of this man . <newline> He was known as 'The Cocaine God '

prompt: The Cocaine God
story:
In the depths of the Amazon rainforest, there existed a legend about a god so powerful, so corrupting, that even the bravest of warriors dared not speak its name: El Dios de la Cocaína. The Cocaine God.

Rumors whispered that El Dios de la Cocaína was once a mortal man, a shaman who had delved too deep into the mysteries of the forest. He had discovered the sacred plant, the coca leaf, and its potent magic. As he consumed the leaf, he felt an intoxicating rush of power and knowledge. But with each passing day, his obsession grew, and his soul began to wither away.

The other shamans, fearing his corruption, cast him out of their tribe. Alone and adrift, El Dios de la Cocaína wandered the forest, searching for a way to restore his lost humanity. He stumbled upon an ancient ritual, hidden deep within the jungle, where the gods themselves had imbued the coca leaf with their essence.

As he performed the ritual, El Dios de la Cocaína felt the power of the gods coursing through his veins. He became one with the coca leaf, and his body began to transform. His skin turned a deep, rich brown, and his eyes gleamed with an otherworldly intensity. His voice boomed like thunder, and his presence commanded respect.

And so, El Dios de la Cocaína was born. The Cocaine God, a deity of excess and decadence. His followers, a tribe of addicts and outcasts, worshiped him with fervor. They believed that by consuming the sacred coca leaf, they could tap into his divine power and achieve a state of ultimate bliss.

But the cost was steep. Those who worshiped El Dios de la Cocaína were forever changed, their minds clouded by the constant rush of the coca leaf. They became slaves to their own desires, unable to resist the allure of the Cocaine God's magic.

One brave warrior, named Kanaq, vowed to bring down the Cocaine God and free his people from his grasp. He trekked deep into the jungle, facing countless dangers along the way. Finally, he came face to face with El Dios de la Cocaína.

The air was thick with the scent of coca leaves as the two enemies locked eyes. Kanaq drew his sword, ready to strike. But as he looked into the Cocaine God's eyes, he saw something there that gave him pause. A glimmer of sadness, a hint of regret.

"Why do you resist?" El Dios de la Cocaína asked, his voice like a gentle breeze. "I am but a god, a servant of the forest. I offer you freedom, Kanaq. Freedom from the chains of your own desires."

Kanaq hesitated, torn between his duty and his curiosity. And in that moment, the Cocaine God vanished, leaving behind only a whisper of his presence. The warrior realized that the true enemy was not the god, but his own addiction.

As Kanaq emerged from the jungle, he knew that he had been forever changed by his encounter with the Cocaine God. He vowed to spread the word, to warn others of the dangers of El Dios de la Cocaína's magic. But deep down, he knew that he would always be drawn to the allure of the Cocaine God's power.

prompt: A Vampire who owns a home in Italy that struggles to stay away from garlic , the sunlight , and holy objects on a daily basis .
story: The stark chords of Tosca begin once again ; Scarpia ’ s motive is the first thing the audience at La Scala Opera hear . Perhaps they are jaded by it , but it still elicits within me feelings from a bygone life . Soon we ’ ll see entrances from Cavaradossi and of course our leading lady , Tosca , forced to do the unspeakable and murder one man to try and save another ’ s life . Poor Tosca ; if only she had known that Cavaradossi was truly given a stay of execution , perhaps she would have accepted Scarpia ’ s demand for intimacy . <newline> The people will then shuffle out of the opera theatre , lazily critiquing the same show that they ’ ve seen entirely too often here in Milan , and go out to the cafés and restaurants that they ’ ve been to many times before . Their lives , seemingly on a loop , continue at their leisurely pace as I sit by in my darkened villa above the streets watching the days pass by . <newline> Acquaintances of mine always asked , “ Why move to Milan ? ” “ You don ’ t know Italian , do you ? ” “ Why now ? ” they ’ d ask with all the sincerity of a Hallmark Valentine ’ s Day card . I ’ m not sure that I ’ d ever have an answer for them , because they were right to question my motives . Why choose to fundamentally change the eternal workings of the vampiric lifestyle ? <newline> For one , the Milanese choose to stay out until the ungodly hours of 1 or 2 o ’ clock in the morning , meaning that my food is usually spiked with the residual alcohol from their Lombardy region chardonnay and pinot bianco by the pint . However , even getting past the eternal hangover that is my life , how do I avoid that villainous vegetable that the Italians seem to put in every dish : garlic . <newline> Oh the dreaded aglio . For so often I took it for granted during my time in Vienna . Stakes could be easily enough avoided with good planning ( an internally locked coffin with plenty of reinforced steel between my face and the world that might wish to destroy me ) , but the Austrians never bothered with garlic quite as often as they do here . <newline> Perhaps I might go back to Vienna and dine off the simple people whose beer consumption is admirable as much as it is shameful . Perhaps I will get back to hearing the operas of Strauss and Mozart , or maybe the occasional performance of Marschner ’ s `` Der Vampyr . '' But for now , I sit like Tosca , in a place I should never wish to be waiting for the right moment to make my escape and be free again . Now , this never sleeping city of Milan holds me hostage with the taste of death on everyone ’ s lips . <newline>

prompt: A Vampire who owns a home in Italy that struggles to stay away from garlic , the sunlight , and holy objects on a daily basis .
story:
The sun was setting over the rolling hills of Tuscany, casting a warm orange glow over the small town of Siena. Alessandro, a vampire who had lived in Italy for centuries, stood in his kitchen, sipping a glass of red wine as he gazed out the window. His eyes, a piercing shade of blue, seemed to gleam with a mixture of longing and frustration.

As a vampire, Alessandro had grown accustomed to the charms of Italy - the rich history, the stunning landscapes, and the warm hospitality of the people. But with great privilege came great difficulty. Simple tasks, like cooking dinner or taking a walk in the park, became daunting challenges.

Garlic, for instance, was a constant threat. The pungent aroma wafted from the kitchen, making his stomach turn and his skin crawl. He had learned to avoid it, but it was a constant battle. His chef, a kind old man named Giovanni, seemed oblivious to the danger, and Alessandro found himself having to politely decline his favorite dishes, like spaghetti carbonara and roasted chicken.

The sun was another enemy. Even a few minutes of exposure could leave him feeling weak and disoriented. He had to be careful, always seeking shade or wearing a hat and sunglasses to protect himself. It was a strange feeling, being a creature of the night, yet still being vulnerable to the very thing that gave him life.

And then there were the holy objects. Alessandro had a small chapel in his home, filled with relics and statues of saints. He had grown up in a devout family, and the symbols of faith held a deep significance for him. But as a vampire, he was forced to avoid them, lest he be tempted by the power of the divine.

As he stood in his kitchen, Alessandro felt like a prisoner in his own home. He longed to be free to enjoy the simple pleasures of life, but the constraints of his condition made it impossible. He thought of all the things he could do, all the experiences he could have, if only he could be like everyone else.

Just then, Giovanni appeared in the doorway, a tray of garlic-infused bread in his hands. "Alessandro, my friend, I made your favorite dinner," he said, oblivious to the danger.

Alessandro's eyes widened in horror, and he quickly pushed the tray away. "Giovanni, please, not the garlic. I'll eat something else."

Giovanni looked confused, but he nodded and disappeared into the kitchen. Alessandro let out a sigh of relief, feeling like he was living a lie. He was a vampire, a creature of the night, and yet he was trapped in a world of sunlight and garlic.

As the sun dipped below the horizon, Alessandro made his way to the chapel, seeking solace in the symbols of faith. He lit a candle and knelt before the statue of Saint Sebastian, feeling a sense of peace wash over him. For a moment, he forgot about the struggles of being a vampire, and simply enjoyed the beauty of the world around him.

But as the night wore on, the memories of his struggles returned, and Alessandro knew he would have to face them again tomorrow. He rose from his knees, feeling like a ghost, a creature of the shadows, forever trapped in a world of contradictions.

prompt: 12.000 years in the future . Civilizations fell and rose . Technology back on renaissance level . Mysterious area where no one can survive . Turns out to be Chernobyl .
story: `` Just a little further '' Stasi said as they walked through the forest . Miyakel was breathing hard , half from the quick pace his sister kept , half from fear of the unknown . Their father told them to stay away from this place ; that a powerful wizard put a poisonous spell from all who entered . Normally they would heed papa 's advice , but when the Smif sisters called them cowards them at school on Godday , he and his sister were compelled to travel here to save face from embarrassment . <newline> <newline> They pass over a creak , and Stasi warned her sibling to not drink from it . `` We do n't know how the wizard poisons people who come here , but it 's best to avoid eating or drinking anything . '' Miyakel dreaded the thought of getting sick and having to reveal the truth to father , so he resisted the urge to quench his thirst . <newline> <newline> Their path was overgrown , but manageable . The ground was more covered than the roads in their town , but was too straight to be a coincidence . It was obvious , even to a child , that this once was created by people as a passage way for many folk . He envisioned a time when it was clear and large caravans traveled through this area in horses and carriages down this road . <newline> <newline> Suddenly his sister put her hand out on his shoulder , and became instantly silent . Miyakel froze , worried that they had come across something sinister . Slowly , she pointed with her other hand . The young boy slowly followed with his eyes until he saw it . A metal pole , twice the his height with a sign on it . Metal was rare , and never used for such a luxury as a sign . <newline> <newline> The writing was grey and dirty , but somehow Miyakel knew at one time they were colorful , that time had eroded all the brilliance the sign once had . He could n't read the ancient text , some of the letters were clear like ( CBL ) , while other appears backward ( R ) or upside down ( A ) . Nonetheless the sounds he could construct from it made no sense to him . <newline> <newline> However , he was transfixed by the symbol . It was a triangle , with what appeared to be a circle . However the circle was an illusion . It was circle but every other 1/6 was missing . Additionally the center was showing , but a ring around the center was also removed . Something had made this sign , and it did so very deliberately . Although he had never seen it before , this symbol was foreboding . His mind was fearful of the alien design . <newline> <newline> Miyakel held his sister 's hand and tilted his head back toward the village . He had seen enough and wanted to go home . Mother would be making a fresh batch of bread , and they still had firewood to gather for the stove . Stasi apparently felt the same . This was as far as they were willing to go . However she pulled out some paper and the piece of sharpened coal that father had gotten her from last Spring 's carnival . She copied what she saw , hoping that one day she could make sense of the sign . After she finished , he watched her carefully open her satchel and place in it the paper that read : `` WARNING CHERNOBYL AHEAD . ''
